questions.text: A patient presents with proptosis that increases when bending down. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Orbital Varices are abnormal dilations of veins in the orbit. They often present with proptosis (bulging of the eye) that can worsen with increased venous pressure, such as when the patient bends down or performs actions that increase intra-abdominal or intra-thoracic pressure.

 

Causes of intermittent proptosis:

  • Orbital varix
  • Periodic orbital oedema
  • Recurrent orbital hemorrhage
  • Highly vascular tumors

 

Orbital Varices

Dilated venous channels in the orbit (part of the spectrum of developmental venous anomalies)

Clinical features

Most cases are unilateral and the most frequent site is upper nasal.

Slowly progressive intermittent proptosis which worsens with head position changes, bending forward, or Valsalva maneuver.

Pathology

May involve one large vessel or multiple ectatic veins with fibrotic walls.

Thrombosed lumens can contain phleboliths from calcified thrombi.

Imaging

CT - serpiginous, dense structures that enlarge with Valsalva, enhances with contrast administration.

MRI - T1 images show low isointense signal, T2 shows dark signal void from flowing blood. Enhancement with Gadolinium is marked, except in areas of thrombosis.

Treatment

No treatment needed for mild symptoms;

Surgical or embolization options for severe cases.

Prognosis

Good unless large lesions compress the optic nerve, risking vision loss.


 

Thyroid Eye Disease (Option B): This condition typically causes bilateral proptosis due to inflammation and fibrosis of the extraocular muscles. While proptosis occurs, it does not usually worsen with bending down and is often associated with thyroid dysfunction. It has a more gradual onset compared to conditions like orbital varices.

Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis (Option C): This serious condition presents with painful proptosis, usually accompanied by headache, cranial nerve palsies, and vision changes. Proptosis does not typically worsen with bending down, and the condition is associated with acute symptoms and systemic signs of infection.

Orbital Cellulitis (Option D): This is an infection of the orbit, causing painful proptosis, redness, and swelling, often accompanied by fever. Pr

questions.text: Which of the following is true about orbital cellulitis?

choices.text: It is present anterior to the orbital septum
Presents with proptosis, orbital swelling, normal pupil, and extraocular movements
Ethmoid sinusitis is the most common etiology

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Ethmoid sinusitis is the most common etiology

  • Orbital cellulitis is an infection of orbital (post-septal) tissues that most often occurs by contiguous spread from adjacent paranasal sinuses. The ethmoid sinuses lie immediately medial to the orbit and separated by the very thin lamina papyracea, making ethmoid sinusitis the single most common source—especially in children.

Orbital cellulitis:

  • Infection of orbital tissues posterior to the orbital septum (Option A) (orbital fat, extraocular muscles, occasionally optic nerve).

Clinical features: Eyelid swelling, erythema, fever, painful, restricted extraocular movements, proptosis, chemosis, decreased vision, possible RAPD (Option C) if optic nerve involved.

Differentiation: Key distinction from preseptal cellulitis is painful ophthalmoplegia, proptosis, and visual compromise in orbital cellulitis.

Investigation: Urgent contrast CT or MRI of orbits + sinuses to define extent, look for subperiosteal/orbital abscess, and identify sinus disease.

Management: Hospitalize → IV broad-spectrum antibiotics (Option B) covering Staph/Strep/H. influenzae/anaerobes; ENT/ophthalmology consult; surgical drainage if abscess or failure to improve.

Complications: Orbital/subperiosteal abscess, cavernous sinus thrombosis, meningitis, intracranial abscess, permanent vision loss—hence early aggressive treatment is mandatory.

questions.text: A 15-year-old female presents with a painless, gradually increasing mass located lateral to the lateral canthus, present for the past 10 years. On examination, the mass is non-tender and slowly progressive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Dermoid cyst

  • A painless, slowly progressive, lateral canthal mass present since childhood suggests a congenital lesion at a suture line, which is most characteristic of a dermoid cyst.
  • Dermoid cysts are congenital choristomas caused by ectodermal tissue being trapped along embryonic suture lines, most commonly at the frontozygomatic suture. They contain epidermis and dermal appendages like hair follicles and sebaceous glands. The lesion is firm, non-tender, and slow-growing.
  • Imaging (CT/MRI) shows a well-circumscribed cyst with fat density.
  • Definitive management is surgical excision with intact capsule to prevent recurrence and inflammation.

Capillary hemangioma (Option B): Appears in infancy, is vascular, red/bluish, and rapidly proliferates before involution — not a 10-year static mass.

Lacrimal gland tumor (Option C): Usually in adults, causes superolateral orbital swelling with globe displacement; may have pain.

Epidermoid cyst (Option D): Contains only epidermis without dermal appendages; location and imaging features make dermoid more likely in this case.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, and chemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was hyperthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Grave’s ophthalmopathy

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, chemosis and hyperthyroidism is suggestive of Grave’s ophthalmology

 

Thyroid Eye Disease Clinical Features :

Clinical Features

Details

Lid Signs

Dalrymple's Sign

Upper lid retraction causing a staring appearance (90% of cases).

Von Graefe's Sign

Lid lag when the globe moves downward (50% of cases).

Enroth's Sign

Puffy, oedematous swelling of the eyelids.

Gifford's Sign

Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid.

Stellwag's Sign

Infrequent blinking.

Joffroy's Sign

Poor forehead wrinkling on looking up.

Kocher’s sign

Increased lid retraction with visual fixation (staring look)

Conjunctival Signs

Deep Injection

Pronounced redness.

Chemosis

Swelling of the conjunctiva.

Pupillary Signs

Less significant; may show unequal dilatation of pupils.

Ocular Motility Defects

Mobius's Sign

Convergence weakness.

Restrictive Myopathy

Limited movement in the direction opposite to the affected muscle.

Exophthalmos

Both eyes are often affected with possible unilateral proptosis.

 

Orbital pseudotumor (Option A) It is characterized by congestive proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and optic nerve dysfunction and generally present as a unilateral condition in adults.

Orbital lymphoma (Option C) It is characterized by discomfort, bulging eye, diplopia, and visible mass and can be unilateral or bilateral..

Orbital cellulitis (Option D) It is the most common cause of unilateral proptosis in children and is characterized by unilateral, painful proptosis and fever.

questions.text: Following instrument is used to measure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Proptosis

Explanation:

The instrument used to measure proptosis is called an exophthalmometer, such as the Hertel or Luedde exophthalmometer. This tool helps assess the degree of ocular protrusion and is particularly useful in diagnosing conditions like proptosis caused by orbital tumors or other space-occupying lesions.

 

Proptosis

  • Proptosis refers to the abnormal protrusion of the eyeball, while exophthalmos specifically describes protrusion of the eyeball.
  • Causes:
    • Retrobulbar lesions (most common cause).
    • Shallow orbit (less common).
    • The optic nerve allows significant forward displacement of the globe (25mm length), causing proptosis without excessive nerve stretching.
  • Types of Proptosis:
    • Axial proptosis: Caused by space-occupying lesions within the muscle cone (e.g., cavernous hemangioma, optic nerve tumors).
    • Combined proptosis and dystopia: Due to extraconal lesions (e.g., lacrimal gland tumor) causing displacement in the coronal plane (dystopia).
    • Dystopia: Displacement of the globe in the coronal plane, either horizontal or vertical. Measured using the midline (nose) for horizontal or a vertical scale for vertical displacement.
  • Measuring Severity:
    • Use a plastic rule, Luedde™ exophthalmometer, or a binocular exophthalmometer (Hertel) for accurate measurements of ocular protrusion.
    • Readings >20 mm or a difference of 2–3 mm between eyes suggests proptosis.
    • Palpebral aperture dimensions and any lagophthalmos should be noted.
  • Pseudoproptosis: A false impression of proptosis due to:
    • Facial asymmetry.
    • Enlarged globe (e.g., high myopia, buphthalmos).
    • Lid retraction or contralateral enophthalmos.

Clinical evaluation of proptosis

  • Differentiate proptosis from pseudoproptosis
    • Pseudoproptosis (the false impression of proptosis) may be due to facial asymmetry, enlargement of the globe (high myopia, buphthalmos), lid retraction or contralateral enophthalmos.
  • Asymmetrical proptosis is readily detected by looking down at the patient from above and behind
  • Globe location: If it is misplaced superiorly, inferiorly, medially, laterally, or straight out (axially) by an exophthalmometer.
    • An exophthalmometer is used to quantify the distance from the orbital rim to the corneal surface of each eye in order to assess the symmetry of globe protrusion. Readings >20 mm are indicative of proptosis and a dierence of 2–3 mm or more between the two eyes is suspicious regardless of the absolute values. (Option B)
    • Hertel's exophthalmometer: In adults.
    • Luedde exophthalmometer: In children.
    • Naugle exophthalmometer: Non-axial proptosis

 

Squint (Option B), also known as strabismus, refers to a misalignment of the eyes, where the eyes do not point in the same direction. The condition is measured using ocular alignment tests (like the Hirschberg test or the Cover test), not an exophthalmometer.

Ptosis (Option C) refers to the drooping of the upper eyelid. The severity of ptosis is usually assessed by observing the degree of eyelid droop, often with the help of a marginal reflex distance (MRD) test or by measuring the distance from the upper eyelid to the corneal light reflex. This is not measured using an exophthalmometer.

Diplopia (Option D), or double vision, refers to the perception of two images of a single object. This condition is typically evaluated through visual field tests, ocular motility testing, and cover tests, not with an exophthalmometer.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Thyroid eye disease:

  • The most common cause of both unilateral and bilateral proptosis in adults is thyroid ophthalmopathy.
  • In children, the most common cause of unilateral proptosis is orbital cellulitis and bilateral proptosis is neuroblastoma.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Orbital varix:

  • Orbital varix causes intermittent proptosis.

Option C - Retinoblastoma:

  • Retinoblastoma does not cause proptosis.

Option D - Cavernous hemangioma:

  • Cavernous hemangioma causes proptosis but it is not the most common cause.

questions.text: What is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Malignant Choroidal melanoma:

  • Malignant choroidal melanoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults. It originates from the pigment-producing cells (melanocytes) in the choroid, which is a vascular layer beneath the retina in the eye. Choroidal melanoma is more prevalent in adults, particularly in individuals with fair skin and light-colored eyes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Retinoblastoma: It is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in Children.

Option C - Reticulum cell sarcoma: Reticulum cell sarcoma, or primary intraocular lymphoma, is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that can occur in the eye. While it is a primary intraocular malignancy, it is less common than malignant choroidal melanoma.

Option D – Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are tumors that arise from nerves. They are often associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), a genetic condition.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female reports recurring episodes of discomfort, pain, and a sensation of pressure behind her left eye. She exhibits intermittent reducible proptosis, and her symptoms intensify when she bends forward. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Orbital varices:

  • Orbital varices are vascular anomalies characterized by dilated and tortuous veins in the orbit, which are associated with intermittent proptosis.
  • Proptosis may worsen when the patient is in an upright position or during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing or bending forward.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Orbital hemangioma: Orbital hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors of the orbit. They typically present as painless, slow-growing masses without the characteristic features of intermittent proptosis.

Option C - Orbital metastasis: Orbital metastasis is less probable because of younger age and the recurrent nature of the symptom.

Option D - Orbital dermoid cyst: Orbital dermoid cyst is characterized by a painless nodule or proptosis.

questions.text: Diagnose the clinical condition as shown in photo:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Limbal dermoid:

  • The image revealed a raised, yellowish-white lesion with hair-like structures in the limbal area (the junction between the cornea and sclera)is suggestive of limbal dermoid, which is a congenital benign tumor is a choristoma consisting of a mass of collagenous tissue containing dermal elements, which is covered by stratified squamous epithelium.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Keratoconus: Keratoconus is a progressive eye condition characterized by thinning and bulging of the central cornea, resulting in a cone-shaped corneal surface. It typically presents as a V-shaped deformity of the cornea (munson’s sign).

Option B - Keratoglobus: It is a familial and hereditary bilateral congenital disorder characterized by thinning and hemispherical protrusion of the whole cornea.

Option D - Pinguecula: Pinguecula is a common degenerative condition of the conjunctiva characterized by a yellowish-white mound near the limbus formed by elastotic degeneration of conjunctival stroma seen in a person exposed to strong sunlight, dust, and wind.

questions.text: During evisceration of the right eyeball, which layer of the eyeball is eliminated?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Middle and inner:

  • In evisceration, the middle layer (uvea) and inner layer (retina) of the eyeball are typically removed while preserving the outer layer (sclera). The procedure involves the removal of the intraocular contents, including the iris, lens, and vitreous humor, while leaving the outer structure intact.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the first sign to be seen in a patient with sympathetic ophthalmitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Retrolental flare:

  • Retrolental flare refers to the presence of protein and inflammatory cells in the vitreous cavity, which can be seen on fundus examination. It is the earliest finding of sympathetic ophthalmia and indicates the presence of intraocular inflammation.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What would be your diagnosis for a patient who has a previous trauma history and is currently experiencing diplopia and following findings on CT?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Blowout Fracture:

  • The clinical presentation and CT showing Teardrop sign is suggestive of blowout fracture. A blowout fracture typically occurs when there is blunt trauma to the orbit resulting in fracture of the thin bones surrounding the orbit leading to teardrop sign due to prolapse of the soft tissue content into maxillary antrum.
  • It is characterized by ecchymosis, enophthalmos, and diplopia due to entrapment of inferior rectus and inferior oblique muscle in the fracture.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Teardrop sign is not seen in these conditions.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presented with concerns about his eyes bulging and becoming more prominent over the past month. He has previously been diagnosed with Grave's disease. The image below shows the patient's eyes. Based on these findings, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Thyroid eye disease:

  • The clinical presentation,history of grave’s disease and the image is suggestive of thyroid eye disease aka Grave’s ophthalmopathy..
  • The image reveals bilateral proptosis, periorbital swelling caused by edema and infiltration behind the orbital septum. This may be associated with chemosis and prolapse of retroseptal fat into the eyelids, dalrymple sign is seen, i.e., lid retraction in primary gaze, and Kocher’s sign, characterized by staring and frightened appearance of the eyes are characteristic of thyroid eye disease.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Orbital cellulitis: Orbital cellulitis is the inflammation behind the orbital septum caused by bacteria or fungi and characterized by unilateral proptosis, chemosis, restricted eye movements.

Option B - Preseptal cellulitis: It is characterized by a swollen, often firm, tender red eyelid caused by staphylococcus aureus and streptococcus pyogenes after a trauma near the eye.

Option D - Capillary hemangioma: Capillary hemangioma is the benign tumor of the orbit commonly affecting infants and is caused due to incomplete blood vessel formation.

questions.text: What is the most common site of an orbital blowout fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Floor:

  • The blowout fracture most frequently involves the floor of the orbit along the thin bone covering the infraorbital canal.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. These walls of the orbit are not commonly involved in the blowout fracture.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding a patient who has a history of falling on a symmetrical surface and presents with enophthalmos, diplopia on upward gaze, and loss of sensitivity over the cheek?

choices.text: It is a blow out fracture
Zygomatic bone is most likely injured

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - It is a blow out fracture:

  • The patient's symptoms, including enophthalmos (sunken eye), diplopia on upward gaze, and loss of sensitivity over the cheek, are consistent with a blowout fracture.
  • A blowout fracture refers to a fracture of the orbital floor or medial wall caused by trauma. It can result in displacement of orbital contents and lead to various symptoms like periocular ecchymosis, enophthalmos, diplopia, and loss of sensation over the cheek because of the involvement of the infraorbital nerve.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. described symptoms are not associated with these fractures.

questions.text: Blow out fracture can be due to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tennis ball injury:

  • Blow-out orbital fractures occur due to trauma to the orbit, which is often caused by a large and rounded object like a tennis ball, cricket ball, human fist, or part of an automobile.
  • The force of the blow causes the eyeball to be displaced backwards and increases intraorbital pressure. This results in a fracture at the weakest point of the orbital wall, which is typically the orbital floor but can also be the medial wall.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: A 5-year-old was brought with the complaints of protrusion of the right eye with no h/o fever. CT scan showed a well – defined mass in the orbit with an irregular border and adjacent bony destruction. Biopsy showed small, round cells which were positive for Desmin in immunohistochemistry. What is the probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Rhabdomyosarcoma:

  • "Rhabdomyosarcoma" is the probable diagnosis based on the given information.
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor that arises from embryonal cells of skeletal muscle origin. It is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in children and can occur in various locations, including the orbit. The clinical presentation of an orbital rhabdomyosarcoma often includes proptosis (protrusion of the eye), without a history of fever.
  • The CT scan findings of a well-defined mass in the orbit with an irregular border and adjacent bony destruction are consistent with the characteristics of rhabdomyosarcoma..
  • The biopsy findings of small, round cells that are positive for Desmin, and Desmin is a marker of rhabdomyosarcomas.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina, which is the inner layer of the eye. It typically presents as leukocoria , strabismus , or visual impairment.

Option B - Cavernous hemangioma: Cavernous hemangioma is a benign vascular tumor that can occur in the orbit. It is characterized by a collection of dilated blood vessels.

Option C - Orbital Cellulitis: Orbital cellulitis is an infection involving the soft tissues around the eye. It typically presents with eyelid swelling, erythema, pain, fever, proptosis, restricted eye movements.
